docs.lead_paragraph: A RESIDENT of New Rochelle became aware of the economic waste in the Medicare system when his mother needed a special bed from a medical equipment company. Medicare paid for the bed and continued to pay for it for three months longer than it was needed, despite repeated phone calls to have it removed. ''That started me thinking if I ever get on Medicare, I'm going to pay attention to the bills,'' said the man, Dr. Irwin Golden, 70, who is semi-retired and has a doctorate in social work. Besides checking his own Medicare statements, Dr. Golden is a volunteer with Operation Restore Trust, a program developed by Federal and state agencies and carried out by the county's Office for the Aging. Through public presentations, the program seeks to teach the elderly how to identify and report suspicious and possibly fraudulent medical bills.

headline.main: Teaching the Elderly to Spot Fraud

docs.abstract: Article on Operation Restore program in Westchester County, NY, that teaches elderly how to spot and report possibly fraudulent medical bills; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Clinton to Intervene as H.M.O.'s Exit Medicare'' (news article, Oct. 8): Health maintenance organizations lured elderly people to sign up with them and collected premiums from the Government. Now, after receiving payment, H.M.O.'s are trying to extricate themselves from what they claim is an unprofitable deal.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's the Friday night opener of the North Bergen Bruins football season, and the team's veteran trainer, Ira Wolfe, stands on the sidelines with his young protege, Martin Mokrzecki, taking in the scene. An intense, almost giddy crowd cheers the first plays as color washes over the field: the maroon and yellow uniforms of the Bruins and the blue and white of visiting Irvington. But the excitement wanes as the Bruins, last year's state champions, quickly run up the score. One of the few moments that command full attention comes when a North Bergen player is hurt in the second half. A hush falls over the stadium, as Mr. Wolfe and Mr. Mokrzecki huddle on the field with the Bruins' three team physicians over No. 52, Jason Lamberti, a senior linebacker. The medical team agrees that Lamberti should sit out the rest of the game, and he walks off gingerly, apparently with bruised ribs.

headline.main: High School Trainers Hope to Boost Their Status

docs.lead_paragraph: State health insurance regulators are reporting surging numbers of formal complaints from patients and doctors against health insurers, primarily health maintenance organizations. They say they doubt that the rise implies a deterioration in care. They tie much of it to greater public readiness to fight H.M.O.'s and to the insurance commissioners' efforts to encourage people to file complaints. ''We are beating the bushes,'' said Neil D. Levin, New York State's Insurance Superintendent.

headline.main: Complaints About H.M.O.'s Rise as Awareness Grows

docs.lead_paragraph: Under an eight-foot-tall Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington, an actor dressed in a slave trader's gold vest sinks to his knees and tells a judge, ''The Negroes had gathered with sabers around my head, and they just started singing my death chant.'' The trader, Don Pedro Montez, pleads for the return of his slaves every Tuesday at the Old State House in Hartford, part of a re-enactment of a trial -- held in that very room -- after the 1839 slave mutiny on the schooner Amistad. Connecticut's capital is known as the city where the world's insurance industry blossomed, where Mark Twain wrote most of his best-known works and where Samuel Colt mass-produced his revolver. But interest in Hartford's connection to the Amistad grew after the Stephen Spielberg movie was released last December. Now, new exhibits, tours and events highlight the area's history as a hotbed of abolition activity.

docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE you are being treated for breast cancer, a fact known to your Travelers' insurance agent from your medical tests and insurance forms. Imagine also that you are applying for a mortgage from, say, Citibank, where you've banked for years and which has just merged with Travelers Group. Despite your excellent credit rating, your mortgage is denied by Citibank for reasons that are unclear. Or suppose you've just inherited lots of money from a relative's life insurance policy and you put the money into your Fleet Bank account. Pretty soon you get a call from a representative of Quick & Reilly, a brokerage firm you have never heard of but which is owned by Fleet. The broker is equipped with surprisingly detailed knowledge of your financial situation -- along with a few ideas about how to invest your windfall.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Privacy Matters: When Bigger Banks Aren't Better

docs.abstract: Article focuses on concern over privacy stemming from merger of banks, brokerage firms and insurance companies, notably over amount of personal and medical information that can be collected under one roof as Congress makes such mergers easier; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Republican plan for a big tax cut having died without coming to a vote in the Senate, Congress scrambled today to put together a far smaller tax package that could win bipartisan support. After giving up hope that the Senate would act on an $80 billion, five-year Republican tax cut plan passed last month by the House, the House Ways and Means Committee today hurriedly considered and then passed, on a unanimous voice vote, a narrow bill to address some of the tax issues that both parties consider most pressing.

headline.main: Congress Works on a Tax-Cut Package That Could Win Bipartisan Support

docs.abstract: House Ways and Means Committee hurriedly weighs and passes on unanimous voice vote tax cut bill that addresses some of issues both parties consider most pressing; package would extend series of expiring tax credits, speed existing plan to let self-employed people deduct all of their health-insurance premiums and provide break to farmers hard hit by drop in farm prices; would cost $5.1 billion over five years and be paid for by raising other taxes; plan hits roadblock when Senate Finance Committee decides to draft own bill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislation to give patients more power in dealing with health insurance companies died today, a casualty of heavy lobbying by the insurance industry and of the sex scandal that has enveloped President Clinton. Supporters and opponents said similar legislation would be back in 1999. But this year's struggle shows once again how difficult it is to pass health care legislation affecting doctors, patients, lawyers, insurers and employers of all sizes.

headline.main: SENATORS REJECT BILL TO REGULATE CARE BY H.M.O.'S

docs.abstract: Senate, 50-47, rejects Democratic bid to consider bill to define patients' rights in dealing with health insurance companies and to regulate health maintenance organizations; Democrats charge Sens Trent Lott, Don Nickles and other conservative Republicans worked with insurers to sidetrack bill; Republicans charge Democrats opposed compromise; photo of Pres Clinton and Democratic members of Congress vowing at White House to revive bill (M)
